title: Peter’s rant about science
content: Peter's pet peeve is when the media presents scientific information as anything but probabilistic. Data is very messy, and therefore the best you can do when an experiment is concluded is increase your confidence in the probability of something being true or being false. There's no proving anything in science.

title: Blue light—How Matt shifted his thinking
content: Matthew talks about how he shifted his thinking about blue light.

title: Blue Light and Sleep
content: Matt has down-regulated his belief in the effects of blue light on sleep. Studies implicating blue light as especially bad for sleep were principally looking at melatonin. The next evolution of the science will be to do two types of studies. Firstly, a study where you use the same amount of light exposure but use different types of lights (type of light being the variable). Secondly, studies where the type of light actually becomes the constant stimulus where you maintain the same light exposure. But in one condition you’re doing something cognitively activating. And in the other condition you’re getting hit with the same light but not doing anything cognitively activating.

title: Caffeine and Disease Risk
content: Matt has added more construct to his beliefs around caffeine, sleep, and disease risk. While most evidence is associational from epidemiological studies, the evidence is mounting that coffee drinkers are less at risk to “a whole constellation of diseases”. There seems to be a very clear association between low-to-moderate caffeine consumption and de-risking health disease conditions. The dose AND the timing make the poison when it comes to caffeine. Matt’s thinking has been shaped after listening to the audiobook called Caffeine by Michael Pollan. Pollan believes that the health benefits are not really due to a cup of coffee, but the fact that the coffee bean itself carries with it lots of antioxidants. Matt now drinks decaffeinated coffee in the mornings.

title: REM Sleep
content: Matt has become even more bullish on the importance of REM sleep. All stages of sleep are important.

title: Importance of REM Sleep
content: REM sleep is particularly important for emotional/mental health and a lack of REM sleep seems to be more deadly than a lack of deep non-REM sleep. Evidence shows that for every 5% reduction in your REM sleep, there was a 13% increase in your mortality risk. REM sleep was the single most predictive variable for your mortality risk.

title: Age-Appropriate Breakdown of Sleep Stages
content: The recommendation for the average adult is for about 20% of your sleep to be consumed by REM sleep. One of the problems with sleep trackers is that it doesn’t tell you what the appropriate amount should be. Matthew is working with Dr. Raphael Vallat who has gathered over 14,000 nights of polysomnography across 14,000 people ranging in age from 5 to 97-years-old. They’ve created statistical models of age-appropriate norms and hope to publish the data soon.

title: Predicting Biological Age with Sleep Data
content: Assuming sleep trackers eventually become close to 100% accurate, using the data from a single night of sleep, it would be possible to predict your chronological age with about a 75% accuracy using machine learning algorithms. This data could contribute towards being able to predict your biological age.

title: Increasing REM Sleep
content: REM sleep is very difficult to modulate in an easy way. Matt has one idea that he’s about to start testing and it has to do with temperature. For deep sleep, you cool the body to actually increase deep sleep—You actually have to warm up to get cold, to get to sleep, and then you have to stay cold to stay asleep and get deep sleep.

title: Thermoregulation and REM Sleep
content: During REM sleep, your temperature is uncontrolled, and going further away from thermoneutrality for your body can disrupt REM sleep. Monitoring your body temperature with a device and controlling it to keep you in the sweet spot of thermoneutrality during the last two hours of your sleep can increase your REM sleep. A device called an Ooler, a water-cooled pad that goes under your mattress, can help with waking up but not for increasing REM sleep. To specifically increase REM sleep, you need a closed-loop system that constantly monitors and tweaks your body temperature to keep you in the sweet spot.

title: Sleep Tracking Wearables
content: When it comes to wearables, Matt thinks about two different criteria: accuracy of sleep data relative to the gold standard of recordings in the sleep laboratory and form factor. The Oura Ring does a decent job of accuracy and has some sensing advantages like body temperature. Being a ring, there's a higher likelihood for compliance, which is important for adherence. Matt is excited to work for Oura to see if he can help improve the accuracy.

title: Electromagnetic Force of Devices and Sleep
content: There is no evidence that the electromagnetic force of devices has any impact on sleep.

title: Electronics and Sleep
content: There’s no evidence that the electromagnetic force of one of those devices impacts someone’s sleep. Perhaps that would change is someone essentially duct-taped a device to their head (only Peter did that in medical school so as to not sleep through getting paged at night). Matt says the first place one might look is at environmental studies where you look at people who are living very close to high-grade, overhead power lines. The problem is that this type of data may not be useful since there would be so many confounding variables.

title: Fasting and Sleep
content: Peter says some of his patients who do multi-day fasting (3+ days) will struggle with falling asleep and staying asleep at night (less so with time-restricted eating or just a 1-day fast). On flip side, the sleep you DO get actually seems remarkable. Peter, for example, notices that the following sleep metrics improve: Heart rate variability goes up by 25- 50%, Resting heart rate goes down, Body temperature goes down, His best nights in terms of staging—Deep sleep is 25%, REM sleep is 25%. Matt commonly hears the following from fasters— They struggle with falling asleep and staying asleep. However, he also hears in many cases that the lesser amount of sleep doesn’t bother them. In other words, they don’t feel as sleepy as they normally would (i.e., that little sleep would normally have them feeling miserable).

title: Orexin and Sleep
content: Orexin turns out to be a wake promoting chemical. So when you release and dump orexin into the brain and the body, it wakes the brain up. Normally it shuts down at night and that’s part of the mechanism of what we call the sleep-wake switch. Orexin, like many other hormones and chemicals, seem to be under the control of our 24 hour circadian rhythm which is regulated by the suprachiasmatic nucleus. Another part of regulation of orexin is independent of your sleep-wake, it’s actually dependent on your body’s energy balance. When animals go under conditions of starvation, these orexin cells sense the change in the energy balance and they start dumping out more orexin which forces the animal artificially awake for a longer period of time. In humans under conditions of fasting, Matt thinks you are giving the body an ancient, evolutionary signal of starvation which causes the brain to dump more orexin into the system and therefore your sleep becomes compressed. *Partial explanation for why sleep metrics improve while in a fasted state:

title: Fasting and Sleep Quality
content: It turns out that while the sleep is compressed, the body makes up for that by increasing the quality of that  sleep (something you see with insomnia patients being treated with sleep restriction therapy). Important note: This is NOT sustainable over the long term. But, it does partly explain the observations of improved sleep metrics, and people subjective feeling like they aren’t as sleepy as they typically would expect due to the shorter

title: Trazodone as a Sleep Aid
content: Trazodone is drug that formerly found its use as an antidepressant at much higher doses, but it wasn’t a very successful. It became a drug that had no application until people realized that it was a pretty good sleep drug preserving sleep architecture. Peter personally has found that 25-50 milligrams of trazodone to be a magic bullet when he’s struggling to sleep due to hunger issues. NOTE: Peter doesn’t recommend this without a doctor’s supervision and only uses in rare instances

title: Restless Leg Syndrome
content: About restless leg syndrome (RLS). It’s a long-term disorder usually characterized by uncontrollable, and really uncomfortable, urge to move your legs (can also happen in other limbs like the arms). People with RLS can’t wear traditional sleep trackers because the motion throws it off. It effects between 5 to 15% of the population. Hypotheses on the mechanisms of why it’s happening. Hypothesis 1: The principle hypothesis is that it’s due a deficiency of dopamine in the brain. Hypothesis 2: RLS is due to an iron deficiency

title: Magnesium Supplementation as a Sleep Aid
content: Peter is a big proponent of something called Magnesium L-Threonate. It is essentially a transporter that, in theory, gets the magnesium into the brain more. He takes two capsules of Magnesium L-Threonate before bed, every night as part of his sleep protocol. He also takes magnesium oxide in the evening. General magnesium supplementation is very commonly taken for sleep. The idea is that it helps relax the body and relax the muscles

title: Magnesium and Sleep
content: There is evidence that people who had sleep disruptions have a deficiency in magnesium (Mg). For those people deficient in Mg, supplementing with Mg could be part of the equation for better sleep. However, that’s a very different things than someone who is NOT deficient could get better sleep by supplementing with Mg. Matt is not aware of any literature showing good causal evidence that magnesium supplementation actually improves someone’s sleep. Absence of evidence is not evidence of absence, so if good scientific studies are done, we may find it helps. The placebo effect is one of the most reliable effects in all of pharmacology, so if you think that magnesium is giving you a benefit to the quality of your sleep, maybe there’s no harm in it. Be cautious — Magnesium as a supplement is unregulated by the FDA. Peter’s preferred brands: Peter’s preferred magnesium L-Threonate is made by a company called Magtein. Peter also likes a magnesium products from Nature Made.

title: Sleep Deprivation and Gut Health
content: Matt says there is evidence starting to emerge about how sleep deprivation leads to poor gut health. Early data is showing that when you sleep deprive either human beings or animals, you see a shift in the gut microbiome balance away from the bacterial bent and more towards the fermented bent of the microbiome. That shift is interesting because there’s an association between poor health outcomes and a gut microbiome with a fermented bent. Using that logic, sleep deprivation is pushing you into a gut microbiome profile that is not optimal. Another experiment mimicked jet lag and it also produced that same deleterious shift towards the fermented gut. More recent data comes from a Harvard paper—If you sleep deprive fruit flies (and rats), they will die. But this study investigated what could be killing the fruit flies when they’re deprive of sleep and they focused in on free radical damage from reactive oxygen species (ROS). They found a vast amount of ROS proliferating—NOT all over the body in all of the major organ systems—but it was expressly happening in the gut of the fruit flies. So something strange is going on in the gut regarding free radical damage caused by a lack of sleep. Next, that same Harvard study did something elegant—They started dosing the flies with ~20 different antioxidants and they were able to keep the flies alive despite sleep depriving them if they treated the reactive oxygen species. The most interesting insight from that study—Melatonin is a remarkable antioxidant. They found melatonin to be one of the chemicals that seem to be beneficial in preventing these reactive oxygen species. Caveat: We don’t know if this is going to be replicated in animals, in mice or rats, and we certainly don’t know if this is true in humans. But if it did, then melatonin could be an interesting counter measure to help us protect human beings when we have obligatory sleep deprivation.

title: Personalized Sleep Medicine
content: Matt would like to create technology that could act as a truly personalized sleep coach. The technology ingests every piece of data about you, including bio-tracking data about your physiology, data about your mental state, and data out of your calendar as to what you’ve been doing, what you’re doing today, and what you’ve got upcoming in your future. After ingesting all the data, for each specific day and evening it would create a personalized, tailored sleep prescription for you. It’s going to tell you the best things for you to do today for your sleep, when you should be doing them, how much of them you should be doing, when you should be trying to get to bed, and when you should be waking up.

title: Predictolytics
content: Matt wants to do something similar with sleep. If you continue sleeping only 5.5 hr/night, this is your disease trajectories (i.e., Alzheimer’s, hormones, mental health, heart disease, etc.). But if you increase your sleep time time to 7, 7.5, or 8 hrs per night, here’s how those things change. The person can then be offered simple suggestions (e.g., bedtime alarm and wake alarm).

title: Super Agers
content: Matt wonders whether or not sleep is an unknown factor that is coming in and creating a cushion, or a force that is a countermeasure against pathology. If you look at this patient’s blood work and you see high C-reactive protein, insulin resistance, and other markers of aging, but yet they still seem to be alive and healthy… Is sleep this countermeasure in all of this? Is sleep and new physiological blue zone?

title: Researching Blue Zones and Centenarians
content: Matt is hoping to get in contact with Dan Buettner who has famously discussed in his TED Talk the idea of “blue zones” where people live a long time — Matt thinks sleep needs to be added into his considerations. Peter also suggests talking with Nir Barzilai who probably has the largest data set on centenarian.

title: Compressing Human Sleep
content: With unlimited resources and unlimited time, Matt says, “One of the things  would like to try and do is find out if I can discover a technological way  to develop some kind of technique where I can compress sleep down to four hours, four and a half hours, and it remains just as good as eight hours of sleep.”
